42.54.text: (Michael Sweere) I tell people that I'm a visual artist

44.74.text: and that I specialize in creating artwork

47.00.text: from recycled and reclaimed salvage material.

51.00.text: When they ask me what does that mean,

53.50.text: I tell them I build mosaics, and I build collages.

57.00.text: When they say well, what's the style like?

59.82.text: I tell them it's somewhere in between fine art and folk art,

63.00.text: and they look at me puzzled,

65.02.text: but they say well, that sounds neat. [laughs]

80.38.text: I started out on my career path

82.10.text: going to school and getting a degree in commercial art,

85.00.text: which led to getting a job in advertising agencies

89.64.text: and I worked as a designer

91.00.text: and art director for almost 20 years.

95.24.text: It started out as a hobby with my son,

98.28.text: and when he was a little kid, we would spend Saturday afternoons

102.36.text: trying to think of projects to do together.

104.38.text: We were having our breakfast in the morning and I said,

107.00.text: we could take this cereal box

109.00.text: and we could make a mosaic out of it.

112.16.text: He said let's do it, and we used a Apple Jacks box.

114.00.text: We got it done, and he thought it was so neat,

117.26.text: he loved, as I cut up pieces, he'd sort out the colors

119.86.text: and we abstractly laid the pieces in, and he looked at it,

122.78.text: and he said it looks like a rabbit jumping out of a hole.

126.30.text: And in an abstract way I thought, it really does,

128.00.text: and that really was the moment when I realized

132.00.text: it's like well, if we could do an abstract rabbit

135.66.text: out of a cereal box in an hour, what if I spent a whole day

139.62.text: or a week working on a mosaic project made out of cereal boxes?

143.32.text: And it clicked, and that's where it all started.

146.00.text: I worked on a lot of packaged goods accounts,

149.00.text: cereal and snack foods and soda,

152.00.text: and consequently I always had an office full of packaging

155.66.text: and I realized that it would be a really fun medium

159.00.text: to learn how to do mosaics with.

161.38.text: I was a little intimidated with just diving in and trying to work with tile or glass,

165.00.text: but paper packaging I had lots of

168.00.text: and I just started cutting up old boxes

171.00.text: and that's kinda how I taught myself the basic techniques

175.00.text: in doing mosaic and collage work.

186.82.text: In 2005 I was able to leave my advertising job

190.32.text: and pursue working on my mosaic and fine art work full time.

198.36.text: When I'm sourcing my materials, most of the recycled, reclaimed,

203.46.text: used stuff that I look for comes from thrift stores.

206.98.text: One blue tile for 25 cents, I'll take that.

210.00.text: This is the Habitat for Humanity ReStore in New Brighton.

216.26.text: For tile, this is the best place to find it.

218.90.text: It's kinda been my hidden secret.

221.44.text: These were probably really expensive at one time.

224.96.text: I don't have a project I can use them on right now, I wish I did.

229.84.text: Somebody else is gonna find these and really luck out.

233.56.text: A whole box of them for $25, that's a pretty good deal.

237.00.text: My favorite kinda tile to work with

246.08.text: Now that I've been doing mosaic and collage work

249.08.text: for the last 10, 15 years, I've got a pretty good collection

253.08.text: of my own material, and in my basement,

255.70.text: I almost have my own thrift store setup.

268.18.text: Sometimes I can do an entire project

270.60.text: just from all the material that I have here.

272.90.text: I have friends and relatives who go out and do picking for me.

276.06.text: Occasionally people will give me old antique plates

278.84.text: that they've had or been in their family collection

281.00.text: and have gotten chipped or broken.

283.72.text: Typically, instead of throwing them out,

285.46.text: they usually ask me if I can use them

287.00.text: and incorporate them into projects, and I just love it.

290.12.text: And often clients will give me old dishware of theirs

293.52.text: because it reminds them of a relative or family member

296.92.text: and I'll try to incorporate that into the actual design too.

318.98.text: Right now I'm working on a tile mosaic backsplash

324.30.text: in the mornings when I've got good light.

326.60.text: I had met with the client a couple months ago

329.02.text: and they told me they would really like to do

331.00.text: a Day of the Dead skeleton theme.

334.76.text: The first thing that I do is a pencil drawing.

337.76.text: Once this was approved by the client,

339.88.text: I took the pencil drawing of the artwork,

342.98.text: brought it to a copy center

344.88.text: and had an oversize black-and-white copy made,

348.10.text: took the copy, laid it down onto a piece of tile board,

352.22.text: and using carbon paper, I transferred that design

355.40.text: and upon transferring it, I use a magic marker

359.26.text: and go over that and get a nice solid outline for me to use,

363.82.text: so it's almost like a coloring book at this point, and now

366.84.text: I just figure out where all the tile colors are going to go.

373.34.text: It's really fun for me, when I find these interesting patterns,

381.42.text: but to kind of hide them, so that as the viewer

384.68.text: sees the piece from a distance, they're drawn into

388.14.text: trying to figure out what it's made of,

390.90.text: or maybe they just like the design,

393.08.text: but I think if there's a real payoff when they go

395.76.text: and they look at it up close, and they see,

399.00.text: well, this landscape that looks like

400.66.text: there's a rainstorm going on, the rain isn't rain,

403.00.text: it's bar codes off of paper packaging or tin packaging.

408.14.text: [12-string acoustic guitar; finger-picking in bright rhythm]

415.56.text: I'm working on a series of tin collages in the afternoons.

421.00.text: they're a whole series of wild animals.

424.00.text: And this is a great horned owl.

437.00.text: A lot of my tin work that I do comes from canisters

440.16.text: that people were gonna just throw in the recycling bin.

443.18.text: And it's rewarding for me to know that,

445.50.text: rather than have somebody throw something out

447.84.text: or just put it in recycling where it gets melted again,

450.42.text: that I can turn it into a piece of artwork.

453.04.text: And it's kinda cool because even the scraps that I don't use,

456.42.text: then I in turn can put those in the recycling bin and there's

460.16.text: not much of a footprint left from any of the work that I do.

463.82.text: I try to get the most usage out of everything.

474.18.text: You can see some of my mosaic work

478.94.text: The Mayo Clinic in Rochester has a couple of pieces of mine.

488.46.text: that I've created for them in the last few years.

491.32.text: Children's Hospital in St. Paul has some work.

494.70.text: When I do work for hospitals or schools or libraries,

501.14.text: there's a sense of reward with it.

502.66.text: Oftentimes the themes that I get to work on are pretty fun.

505.88.text: The artwork is meant to cheer people up

508.00.text: in a kind of a tough situation,

510.00.text: and so to create a piece of artwork

512.04.text: that's designed to try to boost people's feelings

515.28.text: and make 'em feel better, that's rewarding in itself

518.56.text: and occasionally I'll hear back, I'll get an email from somebody

521.74.text: saying, you know, my husband was in the hospital

524.82.text: or my grandmother was there and I was in a really bad mood

527.96.text: and I walked out and I saw one of your mosaics and it made me feel so good.

532.04.text: To get that kind of feedback is just the best feeling in the world,

535.84.text: you know, it just makes me feel like I've got a purpose

538.40.text: for the artwork that I'm creating--I just love that.

554.20.text: [acoustic guitar; slowly strumming, folk music chords]

602.90.text: By the banks of the Ganges

628.00.text: I will settle on her back

631.84.text: And she drifts to the ocean

642.64.text: I could let it wash me down

649.00.text: I could never again be found

681.00.text: From the mouths of the banks

690.16.text: And give thanks to the water that's a giver

716.00.text: For your mouth is a muscle

720.02.text: By your voice they do hustle

726.26.text: And let your voice flow out

729.58.text: And I will join you in song

732.94.text: While we slowly do sing on

797.32.text: [guitar, Hammond organ, drums & bass play slow-tempo R&B]

826.94.text: (Angel Sarkela-Saur) We started painting around 2000. (Andy Saur) 2001.

830.64.text: (Angel) We were both artists, and we loved to go to the coffee shop.

833.94.text: (Andy) Can I get a dark roast and a double-shot Americano please?

838.52.text: (Angel) And we just looked around and thought

841.32.text: why don't we have an art show here?

843.00.text: (Andy) Thank you very much. (man) Thank you.

846.02.text: Since it was taking place in a coffeehouse, like, well,

849.36.text: we should try doing something with coffee.

851.12.text: So we knew that coffee stained, I said well, let's try doing something with that.

855.04.text: (Angel) I think we'll do the wash first and then... (Andy) Okay.

859.08.text: So we thought well let's try like a water color.

867.90.text: (Angel) Well, I absolutely love coffee, and I drink a ton of it.

872.66.text: Not so much, but I appreciate the aroma of coffee too,

875.10.text: I really like that when I'm painting too; it's very pleasant.

885.40.text: (Angel) We get inspired by whatever's around us,

887.70.text: and kind of whatever phase we're in a the time.

889.24.text: So sometimes we're realists and sometimes you know, it's people,

892.96.text: and I love doing hands and faces and things.

896.08.text: But other times we just have whimsical artwork

898.28.text: that's just fun, and a lot of times

900.38.text: we're inspired by the medium of coffee itself

902.94.text: so you'll find that in the subject matter a lot.

904.76.text: Right, a lotta coffee themes, lotta conceptual themes

919.90.text: (Angel) Yeah, it's drying pretty good though. (Andy) It is.

921.90.text: (Angel) This is a good... (Andy) Good wash

924.16.text: (Angel) A nice warm tone to it today. (Andy) Um-hum.

926.78.text: (Angel) A lotta times we use an espresso wash

928.00.text: or we'll take our thick coffee and add water

931.00.text: and it'll vary on the day, what's available to us.

934.22.text: Just kinda get the placement of this. (Andy) No problem.

945.06.text: Painting with coffee is nice because it doesn't require

947.32.text: a lot of extra chemicals or compounds or solvents or oils

950.58.text: or anything like that, so it's very easy cleanup, easy setup,

954.02.text: so it's a fun medium because we can do it in a coffee shop,

957.16.text: we can go out by the shore and paint,

960.04.text: we can just paint anywhere; it's kind of fun to work with.

967.88.text: Today's artwork, we plan to call it Coffee Run,

970.16.text: and it's just fun and whimsical.

972.00.text: These fun little people running with coffee and...

975.06.text: Yeah, it's like, why would you make us run with coffee? [laughs]

987.10.text: (Angel) Maybe after we see how this looks, we'll see if we need...

990.92.text: (Angel) So painting with coffee has its own challenges

993.72.text: because it's just one color, the color brown.

995.94.text: So how do we make it interesting using just one color?

998.84.text: So we have to focus more on the other elements

1001.30.text: such as contrast or layout or form and that sort of thing,

1005.22.text: because we can't use those pops of color to add interest.

1025.56.text: (Andy) Through our artwork, we've been able to travel

1030.10.text: (Angel) And it's really fun to be an artist because we meet

1033.00.text: so many interesting people and just having artwork

1035.00.text: is like such a great way to spur conversation

1039.00.text: and find out about each other and different cultures.

1042.02.text: It really connects people around the world too,

1043.90.text: just through artwork and it's just been a great adventure.

1080.94.text: (Mark Russell Smith) Music is an art of legacy, and the teaching of music

1085.16.text: has always been a mentor-to-student relationship.

1088.96.text: And there's so much knowledge to be passed on,

1091.44.text: enriching for them I hope and certainly enriching for me.

1118.86.text: involved in our 8 school year orchestras.

1122.40.text: so that any student can participate.

1125.14.text: Our students come from all across the region to rehearse once a week.

1139.90.text: (Mark) I am the Artistic Director of GTCYS,

1142.12.text: the Greater Twin City Youth Symphonies.

1143.78.text: As far as conducting goes, my responsibility

1146.32.text: is that top-level orchestra, and that's symphony.

1148.88.text: And this is the orchestra, I think it's fair to say,

1152.00.text: to which all the kids aspire.

1156.16.text: and it varies from year to year, depending on

1158.84.text: the quality of the pool of applicants.

1163.40.text: (Mark) Yeah, these little notes are too short,

1165.92.text: they don't have enough weight okay?

1183.40.text: because we combine full symphony orchestras,

1186.26.text: which has winds, brass and percussion,

1190.98.text: and that creates a very attractive program,

1193.74.text: because of the repertoire that students might not have

1199.60.text: Crescendo on the 4th beat-- Bom ba da

1204.12.text: Continue the crescendo on the 4th beat with an accent.

1215.50.text: (Mark) It is my job to challenge them, to educate and enrich

1220.16.text: and teach music and teach the repertoire and, of course,

1224.64.text: discipline and teamwork and individual preparation.

1228.02.text: Any orchestra can play loud and fast,

1229.60.text: but the really good ones sustain and can play soft things,

1232.94.text: and this is where it's a tremendous challenge. Right?

1235.56.text: Most kids cannot do this, but you guys can.

1237.54.text: You learn about the creative process

1239.96.text: and you learn about patience, you learn cooperation, it's

1243.00.text: using music to make a really well-rounded, educated person.

1278.06.text: The very top students learn to play an entire symphony,

1282.12.text: not just a movement, not just part of it,

1284.42.text: but really getting the breadth of the entire piece.

1287.20.text: In the past we've done Tchaikovsky's 4th Symphony,

1291.94.text: this year Dvorak's New World Symphony,

1293.78.text: that's an important part of their training as musicians.

1296.68.text: Do you want us to switch around the chord at the end

1299.22.text: or do you want us to separate it as we did before?

1301.82.text: What are you on, D-flat? (woman) Mm-hm.

1303.10.text: Just leave it, leave it, that sounds fine to me.

1305.30.text: I need a little more on the bottom of this D-flat.

1308.06.text: One of the things I love most about GTCYS

1310.00.text: is that they just choose the best repertoire,

1313.28.text: 'cause especially my instrument's role in them.

1315.02.text: But the bass has such a rich sound within these pieces.

1317.92.text: (Mark) Three, four! [GTCYS plays in rapid rhythm]

1324.40.text: (Alice) I started GTCYS when I was in my sophomore year.

1327.62.text: It's been incredible, I've been able to be mentored

1330.40.text: by some of the best musicians in the community.

1333.26.text: I just get so excited whenever I listen to classical music

1336.00.text: because being in a symphonic orchestra

1338.02.text: really makes you understand how exciting each line is

1341.06.text: and each phrase is, which is

1342.86.text: what changed my whole view of music.

1356.74.text: I try to practice for 2 hours a day.

1359.06.text: Usually if there's a melody going on during the bass line,

1362.04.text: I'm hearing that in my head.

1363.42.text: A lot of the times I just like to focus on the bass line

1365.76.text: 'cause it's one of the best parts of the symphony,

1368.14.text: but it's really exciting to hear how your part

1370.18.text: would be able to meld in with the other pieces

1371.66.text: and how you should work on your phrasing

1374.28.text: in order to fit with other melodies or counterparts.

1384.86.text: (Megen) Throughout the year, our 8 orchestras perform on average

1391.88.text: We also reinstated a very longstanding tradition

1397.34.text: Our 10-day tour to Spain included 3 concerts,

1401.12.text: performing the music that they love and have learned and worked so hard on.

1405.04.text: When we played a concert in Seville,

1406.94.text: the audience was just so enthusiastic.

1411.06.text: Our music allowed us to connect with people from

1414.06.text: entirely different cultures; and it really did change my life.

1416.96.text: (Mark) We're rehearsing now for Friday's concert,

1419.00.text: where we are at the Ordway prior to SPCO.

1423.00.text: (Megen) Since 2011, GTCYS and the Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra,

1426.70.text: the SPCO, have had a very robust partnership, which has provided

1431.10.text: great access for GTCYS students to the Ordway.

1433.92.text: I think the opportunity to play at the Ordway,

1436.52.text: to play at Orchestra Hall, is unique

1439.58.text: and it's a real challenge for the students

1442.04.text: because the way one has to project,

1444.48.text: the way one has to sustain is, is much different.

1457.46.text: (Alice) Before the concert, everyone is just so excited

1460.08.text: because this is what we've been working for all trimester.

1462.84.text: I always pay close attention to how the orchestra sounds

1466.58.text: within that venue, because it's so completely different

1469.50.text: from where we're rehearsing, and that's how I've grown

1472.62.text: as a musician in GTCYS, is realizing

1474.62.text: that I really need to pay attention

1476.62.text: to how the other instruments are shaping the piece.

1479.50.text: So you really do have to work together

1481.36.text: to produce the best performance that you possibly can.

1484.36.text: [GTCYS plays in tune, in rhythm and in sync with each other]

1489.02.text: Promise me this is the sound you're gonna make,

1491.02.text: okay, that's the sound we're gonna make an hour from now.

1493.40.text: That's the kind of string sound we have to have.

1495.80.text: (Alice) I just can't believe that I get to perform these pieces,

1498.00.text: in these venues, with these other talented musicians,

1501.38.text: and it's just so exciting to be there in that moment.

1525.30.text: (Megen) I love the connection with our students and our families.

1529.26.text: I've seen our kids grow up in the program

1531.74.text: and watching that transformation and connecting

1534.46.text: with others in the community who are as passionate

1537.46.text: about music education as we are.

1540.98.text: (Mark) I love what I do because I love the music so much.

1545.16.text: Bringing that music to life and absolutely

1547.70.text: it does enrich those kids' lives.

1550.66.text: (Alice) GTCYS has been able to foster me,

1552.92.text: not only as a musician, but as a person,

1555.00.text: and I know that once I leave GTCYS,

1557.00.text: I'll come away as a more passionate person

1561.26.text: and also a much more knowledgeable and experienced musician.
